body: This should use a context manager instead of filtering the warning in all cases. e.g., see https://docs.python.org/2/library/warnings.html#temporarily-suppressing-warnings
Thanks, @shoyer, I've made the change.
can u run the vbench suite - this is called a lot (though maybe not so much on object arrays)

that's what I thought

do u want to attempt a cython routine?
should be pretty straightforward ?

look in pandas/lib.pyx

you can start with something like isnullobj but takes an object array of 1-d and returns a bool

untested, but I think something like this should work (you can put in lib.pyx)

```
# return ((left == right) | (pd.isnull(left) & pd.isnull(right))).all()

# these are already object so no need to make sure
lib.array_equivalent_object(left.ravel(), right.ravel())

@cython.wraparound(False)
@cython.boundscheck(False)
def array_equivalent_object(ndarray left, ndarray right):
    cdef Py_ssize_t i, n
    cdef object lobj, robj

    n = len(left)
    for i from 0 <= i < n:
        lobj = left[i]
        robj = right[i]

        # we are either not equal or both nan
        # I think None == None will be true here
        if lobj != right:
            if _checknull(lobj) and _checknull(right):
                continue
            return False
    return True
```
I'm using `test_perf.sh -b master -t equal-warning -r unequal`; I'm not sure why `frame_object_unequal` ran the first time (when using a contextmanager), but not now...

@unutbu so my routine worked as is? I didn't even test it...hahah

ok this looks good (need any more tests?)
_is this always an object array?_: `lib.array_equivalent_object` will get called when `left` is an object array. `right` might not be.

@unutbu hmm, so wrap with `com._ensure_object(...)` (which will make it one if necessary
may need some tests

@jreback: Sorry, I mispoke. It is documented in `array_equivalent`'s doc string that `left` and `right` are assumed to have the same dtype. We check the dtype in the `equals` method(s) before calling `array_equivalent`. So if `left` is an object array, I think we can assume `right` is an object array without having to call `com._ensure_object`.

you need to wrap both left and right (before passing) with `_values_from_object` (which makes them an ndarray if necessary), which is why the timeseries types fail

and maybe add a check if `type(left) != type(right)` somewhere? (is it needed?)

e.g. `Index([1,2,3]).equals(np.array([1,2,3])` should be False?

The test was failing because I was calling `lib.array_equivalent_object` in two places; the second one on float arrays.  Current commit fixes this.

Note I've also modified v.0.13.1 to fix the type Joris [pointed out](GH 8509). The new example shows DataFrames must have indexes in the same order for them to compare equally.
Can you explain what `_values_from_object` is for? When do these objects have a `get_values` attribute?

_is their an example in basics.rst as well?_: Yes, there we show `(df+df).equals(df*2)`. Sorry I can't seem to add line notes; my browser is too old and github seems to no longer cooperate with it. Will upgrade my OS when I build up enough courage.

`get_values` will do dense conversions. All `_values_from_object` does is `getattr(v,'values',v)` iow if it has a values attribute (e.g. its a pandas object), then get the underlying ndarray.

`.values` is 'guaranteed' to not do much (and simply be an attribute access).

`.get_values()` might do more (for certain types), e.g. `Categorical/SparseArray`
@unutbu hahah, about the example, I only mentioned the example because you added to some stuff in v0.13.0. If you think its appropriate add to basics.rst as well.
Hold on then -- It's also part of the doc string contract that `left` and `right` are NumPy arrays. So we shouldn't need to call `_values_from_object`.
Something else wonky going on then: see this test https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tseries/tests/test_base.py#L81

This: https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/index.py#L1050

should be: `array_equivalent(self.values,other.values)`
actually `core/index.py` needs a bunch of updates for this same thing (they should ALL be sending in their underlying values). my bad.
`nosetests pandas/tests/test_base.py` is passing for me locally. Maybe my local changes haven't been pushed properly.
`pandas/tseries/tests/test_base.py` (its a DatetimeIndex as an object) (this is somewhat new, I moved it when I added `TimedeltaIndex`)
their are 4`def equals` in `core/index.py` all need changing as above (and `FloatIndex` (though `Float64Index` can use its existing because it cannot by definition have anything but `NaN`).

you need to change `_checkull` and use something like this: https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tslib.pyx#L573

I don't think this is exported. BUT, I think you can simply move it `lib.pyx` (then put a ref back in `tslib.pyx`)

@jreback: I think I need some help with the Cython. I can get `nosetests pandas/tseries/tests/test_base.py` to pass if I change `_checknull` to `checknull_old` in lib.pyx/array_equivalent_object, but I'm not sure what is the correct way to fix `_checknull`.

nvm what I was writing above

_checknull should work

only difference with that and _checknull_old is that old checks for infs
